What is Statistics?

title: ECO 230 – Week 1 Lecture
text:
Analytics Definition
Analytics is the art of finding out what is in your data.

title: ECO 230 – Week 1 Lecture
text:
Analytics vs. Certainty
If you can (with some effort) find the answer with certainty you are using analytics.

title: ECO 230 – Week 1 Lecture
text:
Analytics vs. Statistics (1)
Analytics deals with what you know.
Statistics deals with what you do not know.

title: ECO 230 – Week 1 Lecture
text:
Analytics vs. Statistics (2)
Analytics helps you get good questions.
Statistics helps you get good answers.

title: ECO 230 – Week 1 Lecture
text:
Statistics as Decision-Making
Statistics is the science of making decisions under uncertainty.

title: ECO 230 – Week 1 Lecture
text:
ETL Overview
Extract – Transform – Load

Extract: get data from its source to your working environment

Transform: clean, standardize, reshape to a consistent structure

Load: place the prepared data into the analysis tool (Excel, R, Tableau, DB)

title: ECO 230 – Week 1 Lecture
text:
Transform Emphasis
Extract – Transform – Load
Edit data so it is stored in a consistent and efficient way.

title: ECO 230 – Week 1 Lecture
text:
Load Destinations
Extract – Transform – Load
Destinations: Databases, Excel, R, Tableau, SPSS

title: ECO 230
text: Topic: Extract, Transform, Load (ETL)

title: Study Guide — Video 1
text:
Understand the purpose and sequence of the ETL process.
Distinguish between raw, unstructured, and structured data.
Recognize why transformation is central to analysis.
Identify common data sources and loading destinations.

title: Study Guide — Video 1
text:
Extract = Getting the data from its source (database, website, sensor feed, file, etc.).
Transform = Cleaning, formatting, reshaping, and standardizing so it’s consistent.
Load = Bringing the cleaned data into the tool where analysis happens (Excel, R, Tableau, DBs).
Most analysis work happens in the Transform stage.
Data from third‑party sources often requires substantial cleanup.
Structured vs. unstructured sources influence how much transformation is needed.

title: Study Guide — Video 1
text:
Moving data from source → computer or tool. This could be downloads, APIs, database connections, or streaming sources.



Ensuring variables are consistent: - date formats
- numerical types
- categorical codes
- missingness
- pivoting between tall/wide
This enables charts, summaries, and models to behave predictably.



Final storage in the analysis environment.
Sometimes data is loaded back to the original DB; sometimes directly into R, Excel, etc.

text:

“Give me 3 messy data scenarios and ask me how I would transform each one.”
“Quiz me with 5 increasingly challenging questions about ETL and explain why each answer is right or wrong.”
“Show me a before/after example of transforming poorly formatted data into tidy data ready for analysis.”

title: Transcript — Video 2 (Measurement Scales)
text:
Transcript — Video 2 (Measurement Scales)
So once you have an idea of what data is in our dataset, how it’s tract, it’s good to take a look at those variables and think, Okay, how is this data is actually stored? Either How was it coded? How is it stored numerically? Is that gonna be useful for us? Is it going to be, is it going to tell us the information that we need? Or do we need to go look at data from a different source?
So textbook definition of how data is measured is as follows. As follows. Here, we talked a little bit about those categorical variables. There’s numeric variables. But this type of data and how it’s stored. It is also important to know what’s the scale that the date is on. So textbook definition, we have nominal ordinal, interval and ratio scale data. And this is getting into, once we have this data, numerically, what we do with it mathematically.
Nominal scale is the lowest level. This is a naming type verbal, so the categories that we have are just there for naming purposes just to keep track of. Okay. This person isn’t, this, isn’t this category or not. It’s usually a categorical type scale.
Ordinal scale is the same sort of thing. We looked at this a little bit with categorical scales where there’s some order inherent to the, to the way the data is tracked.
(… transcript continues …)

title: Transcript — Video 1 (ETL)
text:
Transcript — Video 1 (ETL)
It’s usually one of our first task is figuring out how to get the data where we need it to be in order to use it and do our analysis on it. So generally when we’re getting data, it’s going to follow this type of a process, extract, transform load or ETL process. A lot of the data that we’re gonna be working with, especially for this course, is going to be data that other people have gathered what’s known as secondary data. Later on in the class, we will talk little bit about primary data, how to, how to gather data for a specific purpose. But the vast majority of the time we’re gonna be using data that’s already existing and whether it is from a third party source or internally within our company has sales database or something like that. We usually don’t have a lot of say in how their data is structured, how it’s set up. So we need to figure out how to get that data in the form that it’s in currently. And then get it into a form that we’re gonna be able to do. Our nails the sun.
The first step in that process is to extract the data. And that is to get the data from wherever it is to our computer, to where we’re gonna be working with it at. That data can take on a number of different forms. Sometimes the data is relatively clean. If it is a something like this where we have a structured database where everything is set up just so you know, each point of data is in its own row, each specific variables in its own column. So sometimes it might be pretty much in the form that we need to use it, right where it is.
Other times you might be grabbing it from a website or something like that. If you wanted to do some analysis looking at census data, you will go to the Census Bureau’s website and download data from there. It might just be unstructured data just pouring into, into a database, some sort of a sensor or something that is tracking data, looking at a motion sensor or something like that. Where, you know, every time that that sensor is triggered, it it changes from a truth or false yes or no sort of a thing. Measuring the brightness or measuring the voltage of a certain sensor. Measuring whether or not motion was detected on a video camera. That data might just be constantly pouring in. And then we have to figure out, okay, how we’re gonna deal with this L. We’re going to figure out what the timestamp was. What does this data, what is it telling us?
That first step is to is to extract that data. So get it out of where it is right now. Get it to where we need it to be. Once we have that data downloaded or transferred over to where we’re gonna be using it or connected to, you know, sometimes we don’t actually need the data, we just make a connection to where it’s at. Next step is to transform that data to get it into a format that’s going to be convenient for us to use that we can do analysis on without a constantly having to go in and edit things and change things and recalculate. So that’s the T part of the ETL process transform to get the data from the form that it’s in when we get it, to change it to the form that we’re gonna be using it for our analysis.
So a lot of times we’re editing this data, so it’s gonna be stored in a consistent way. It’s gonna be efficient for us to go and look at it. There’s certain rules that we’re going to follow that’s gonna make our lives much easier when it comes time to analyze that data or build a chart or do some analysis on it. There are some standard ways to keep that where any tool that we’re going to connect to that data width is going to be able to look at it in a similar way.
The example on the top here, that a good before if we download data from the Census Bureau, It’s gonna look something like this. So this data is stored in a way where we have gigabytes of data on. However many million people live in the country. All that data is stored on a server somewhere in a way that’s going to be convenient for the Census Bureau. That’s not necessarily convenient for us. You can see we have a lot of empty space here. If category one, category to category three, you might not know what those things mean.
A lot of times we need to transform that data to get it into something. It’s going to be a little bit more convenient for us to use consistent way to measure what was the time that his data was recorded? Consistent way to measure geographically, what was their zip code? What was the date of what was what were the different categories that it falls into? A lot of times we can store that in a much more efficient way. We do it as part of the transform process.
Last step then is to load it into the program that we’re gonna be using to do our analysis. In this can be anything. Sometimes we go from a database, we transform it and put it right back into that same database. This doesn’t necessarily have to be different programs that we’re using.
(… transcript continues …)

title: Study Guide — Video 3
text:
Identify the unit of analysis in any dataset.
Distinguish cross‑sectional, time‑series, and panel data.
Understand dimensions vs. measures.
Recognize tall vs. wide data structures.
Apply the four principles of tidy data.






Unit of analysis = what each row represents.
Cross‑sectional = different subjects at one time.
Time‑series = measurements over time (subjects may differ).
Panel = same subjects over time.
Tall data = many rows; good for grouping, pivoting, combining.
Wide data = many columns; good for fast lookups.
Dimensions = categories for slicing/filtering (e.g., person, month, location).
Measures = numeric values to summarize (e.g., mean sleep minutes).
Tidy data principles:

Variables in columns

Observations in rows

One table per observational unit

Keys connect tables








The entity described by each row (person, transaction, date, etc.).



Categorical descriptors used for slicing or grouping.



Numerical values used for summaries like average, count, standard deviation.



Two orientations of the same underlying information.








Which dataset structure is ideal for pivoting between categories?


Wide



Tall
Correct answer: B


A dataset tracking the same individuals every month is:


Cross‑sectional



Time‑series



Panel
Correct answer: C


“Month, Location, Person” in a sleep‑tracking dataset are:


Measures



Dimensions
Correct answer: B







Describe a dataset from real life and identify its unit of analysis.

Explain why tall datasets are usually easier to join and aggregate.

Describe when you would prefer a wide dataset.







“Convert a wide dataset to tall format and explain the impact on analysis.”
“Give me examples of cross‑sectional, time‑series, and panel data from everyday life.”
“Ask me 5 questions that require identifying unit of analysis errors.”
“Give me messy untidy data and ask me to reorganize it into valid tidy format.”

title: ECO 230 — Week 1
section: Each variable you measure should be in one column
text:
Each variable you measure should be in one column

Each observation of that variable should be in a different row
There should be one table for each type of observational unit
If you have multiple tables you need a key to link them
Principles of Tidy Data

title: ECO 230 – Week 1 Lecture
text:
ECO 230
Section 005

title: Study Guide — Video 2
text:
Identify each measurement scale (nominal, ordinal, interval, ratio).
Recognize when averages make sense and when they don’t.
Understand discrete vs. continuous variables.
Know how variables are coded behind the scenes.






Nominal = categories without order (e.g., shirt color, ZIP code).
Ordinal = categories with order (e.g., GPA brackets, class rank).
Interval = numeric scale without a meaningful zero (e.g., Fahrenheit).
Ratio = numeric scale with a real zero (e.g., GPA as a continuous number, height, weight).
Discrete = whole units (e.g., number of people).
Continuous = can take fractional values (e.g., weights, GPAs).
Averages are meaningful for ratio data; sometimes meaningful for ordinal; rarely meaningful for nominal.
Computers assign numeric codes to categories, but that doesn’t make them numerical.







Categorical labels without inherent order.



Categories with meaningful ranking, but distances between categories are unknown.



Numeric scale where differences make sense but zero is arbitrary.



True numeric scale with a real zero; ratios are meaningful.








Which scale is GPA when recorded exactly (e.g., 3.27)?


Nominal



Ordinal



Interval



Ratio
Correct answer: D


On which scale does it not make sense to compute an average?


Nominal



Ordinal



Interval



Ratio
Correct answer: A


“Freshman → Sophomore → Junior → Senior” is:


Nominal



Ordinal



Interval



Ratio
Correct answer: B







Give an example of why treating nominal data as numeric can be misleading.

Explain why Fahrenheit is an interval scale.

Describe a variable you use in real life and identify its scale.







“Explain each measurement scale using analogies from sports or gaming.”
“Give me 10 examples of variables and ask me to classify their scale.”
“Convert a ratio variable into an ordinal scale and explain what information is lost.”
“Give me trick questions that test whether I understand when averages make sense.”

title: Transcript — Video 3 (Tidy Data & Structure)
text:
Transcript — Video 3 (Tidy Data & Structure)
So we’ve talked a little bit about how to get the data that we need into our hands onto your computer to do our analysis. Once we have our data ready to go, It’s always good to open up that dataset, take a look at it and get a sense of what is this data actually going to be telling us? How is the houses data stored? Is it in a format that’s gonna be, it’s gonna be useful for analysis. Or do we need to do some additional work in that transform space where we’re getting that data set up and organized just how we want it.
First thing to think about is, how is this, these variables, this data is measuring. How is that data being stored or represented in our spreadsheet or in the database that we’re looking at. It’s usually going to break into two main categories. Categories as a category here. So this would be if our data has discrete things that it’s measuring.
Simple example would be like a true‑false variable. Does this person live on‑campus true or false? It’s going to be a one or a zero. Logical yes or no, sort of a thing.
(… transcript continues …)

title: ECO 230 – Week 1 Lecture
text:
What is Statistics?






What is statistics?


Analytics is the art of finding out what is in your data.


If you can (with some effort) find the answer with certainty you are using analytics.


Analytics deals with what you know.
Statistics deals with what you do not know.


Analytics helps you make good questions.
Statistics helps you get good answers.


Statistics is the science of making decisions under uncertainty.

title: ECO 230 – Week 1 Lecture
text:
Analytics vs Statisics






What is statistics?


Analytics is the art of finding out what is in your data.


If you can (with some effort) find the answer with certainty you are using analytics.


Analytics deals with what you know.
Statistics deals with what you do not know.


Analytics helps you make good questions.
Statistics helps you get good answers.


Statistics is the science of making decisions under uncertainty.





Open with intuition: students already do analytics informally.
Emphasize uncertainty as the key dividing line.
Pause after the third fragment and ask for examples.
